If you’re not sure, make a list of everything vying for your attention.  

Cross off anything that is not important right now.  

GET THE FUTURE OUT OF YOUR HEAD  

Getting the future out of your head enables focus on “what is important now.”  

My next step was to sit down and list things that might be essential.  

I opened to another page in my journal.  

This time, I asked myself, “What might you want to do someday as a result of today?”  

This was not a list of firm commitments.  

It was a way to get all of the ideas out of my head and on paper.  

This had two purposes.  

First, it ensured I wouldn’t forget about those ideas.  

They might prove useful later.  

Second, it alleviated that stressful feeling to act upon them right now.  

PRIORITIZE  

After this, I prioritized each list.  

Then I worked on each item on the “what is essential now” list one at a time.  

I just calmly worked through the list.  

I erased each item when it was complete.  

By the time I went to sleep, I had done all the things that needed execution.  

I had executed them better and faster because I was focused.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Focusing on what is essential in the present moment enhances productivity and reduces stress.
